learningContent.title: Adding basic elements to a concept topic

lcInstruction.p:
Some of the most commonly used elements in a concept topic include

(paragraph),

    (unordered list),
      (ordered list), and (note or admonition). These elements were covered in the Introduction to DITA course. This lesson gives a brief review of these elements and shows how to add them to a concept topic.

step.info: The <ul> element is for unordered or bulleted lists.
The <ul> element can only contain the <li> element, and it must contain at least one.

Each
  • element contains the text for a bulleted entry in the list. In this example, the
  • elements follow the best practice of wrapping a

    element around the text.

step.cmd:
After the
    element, add an
      element with an introductory

      element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre:
Wild duck species

North American wild ducks belong to one of the following categories:

  • Dabbling ducks

  • Diving ducks

  • Sea ducks

  • Whistling ducks

  • Swans and geese

The longest species of dabbling ducks in North America are:

  1. Northern pintail

  2. Mallard

  3. American black duck

step.info: The <ol> element is for ordered or numbered lists.
Like the <ul> element, the <ol> element can only contains <li> elements, and it must contain at least one.

In this example, each of the
  • elements wraps a

    element around the text. Use the

      element only to show that the list items should appear in a certain order, not to create step-by-step instructions. The task topic is intended for instructional content and provides a more semantically rich structure for steps than the concept.

step.cmd: After the <ol> element, create a <note> element and populate it as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre:
Wild duck species

North American wild ducks belong to one of the following categories:

  • Dabbling ducks

  • Diving ducks

  • Sea ducks

  • Whistling ducks

  • Swans and geese

The longest species of dabbling ducks in North America are:

  1. Northern pintail

  2. Mallard

  3. American black duck

Although the northern pintail is the longest dabbling duck, the mallard is generally considered the largest because of its heavier body weight.
